description.narrative: Kosovo Civil Society Foundation program/core support 2015-2018
Kosovo Civil Society Foundation program/core support 2015-2018

Sida support covers all KCSF core activities as laid out in the KCSF Programmatic Strategy. The overall goal of KCSF Programmatic Strategy is to enable civil society for the democratic development of Kosovo. The intended overall goal is the ultimate result of KCSF’s theory of change, which is the overarching logic of its strategy. On achieving the indented goal, KCSF has set the following anticipated mid-term results: Competent civil society to empower citizens' potential for Kosovo's democratic development; Civil society initiatives and partners mobilized and supported to enhance civil society role on Kosovo's democratic development; and, Evidence-based arguments produced and utilized in the policy debate on civil society development and the European integration process.

title.narrative: Agreement on core support to KCSF 2015-2018
Amendment to the agreement on core support to KCSF 2015-2018
Tilläggsbeslut för insatsen Stöd till KCSF

description.narrative: During 2019 KCSF completed the restructuring of the organisation and filled several new positions. These changes have required continuous internal capacity assessment to define skills' gaps with subsequent capacity building, individually and collectively. Simultaneously KCSF moved to new physical premises. This has been a relatively smooth process and although the organisation has grown, the core activities of fund-forwarding and providing training opportunities for CSOs have continued unimpaired. Advocacy work has been a bit slower than expected the last twelve months, mainly due to the absence of a functioning government. KCSF does not collaborate with governmental agencies, but participates in the continuous dialogue between the civil society and different ministries, especially the ministries of public administration, local governance and EU integration. A lot of KCSF's focus lately has been on setting up the pool funding mechansim EJA (Engagement for Joint Action). It was formally launched early March 2020. The process has been comprehensive and KCSF's communication with donors (SDC and the Swedish Embassy) has been working satisfactorily. Development of EJA is quite a feat and one of the strategic long term achievements, which would have been impossible to explore without core support from the Embassy. To prepare for a second phase of core support, the Embassy ordered an independent mid-term review of KSCF. The overall assessment of KCSF is positive and the review states that "KCSF is recognised as an efficient organisation and, with the introduction of a pooled funding mechanism and the promise of donors to join this, is expected to become even more efficient." The Embassy also had an efficiency audit carried out, focusing on internal control mechanisms of forwarding of funds. KCSF came out very well and the audit stated that "following our observations and based on our interviews with KCSF’s representatives, we consider the organization to have an adequate internal control environment to ensure quality and accuracy for managing the process of the grants assessment cycle for sub-granting funds." The audit was shared with SDC and the recommendations have been taken up by KCSF when formulating procedures for EJA. KCSF has developed a new monitoring and evaluation system, which aims to measure effects in a context with several external factors, which normally makes attribution of results difficult. The system measures development through using “ladders of change” in behaviour among the target groups of KCSF (CSOs, civil servants and politicians/decision makers). The monitoring process includes extensive data collection, data processing and strategic reflection. Every six months, the data will be processed and evaluated.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
